Question 2.Question: An obstacle to international trade is
Question 2.Explanation: International trade refers to the buying and selling of goods and services between two or more countries. The three major barriers to international trade are natural barriers, such as distance and language; tariff barriers, or taxes on imported goods(cost of finance); and nontariff barriers. The nontariff barriers to trade include import quotas, embargoes, buy-national regulations, and exchange controls

Proxy

Question 3.Explanation: The ownership right of goods and properties is what is referred to as the Title. Such individual has legal and optimum right over such commodity. This document also spells out what the land can be used for; residential, commercial or mixed development.

Question 6.Explanation: Specific goods are goods that are manufactured and acquired by the seller after the contract of sales. These goods specifically identified at the time a contract of sale is made, e.g. a shirt made of cotton and with a Power Rangers cartoon on it.

Question 7.Question:
Use the information below to answer this question

Ojo purchased the following items from Sani at the specified prices on credit

200 cartons of milk at ₦1,000 per carton; 150 bags of sugar at ₦500 per bag; 50 bags of rice at ₦3,000 per bag.

Sani allowed 10% trade discount and 5% cash discount, if payment is made within the agreed period. Ojo paid within the agreed period.

What was the amount paid by Ojo?
Question 7.Explanation:
Trade discount = 10/100 × 425,500

:. 425,000 - 42,500 = N 382,500

Cash discount = 5/100 × 382,500 = 19,125

:.Amount= 382,500 - 19,125

= N363,375

The amount paid by Mr. Ojo was N363,375

Options.Value: ₦42,500
₦27,500
₦22,500
₦20,000

How much was the trade discount?
Question 8.Explanation: Trade discount = 10/100 × 425,000 = #42,500

Question 50.Explanation: A Central Bank is the apex bank of any country. It is only one in a country as it is the banker's bank. One of the underlying functions of the Central Bank is public debt management. Central banks have an interest in how the government uses bond markets.
